replies.author: @Kingoftherednex
replies.text:
It's always amused me that one of Lincoln's political allies who opposed secession is the "Voice of the South," the guy who would represent the Confederacy if anybody does in a disputed quote.  Is there any US vice-president this applies to?  Are Mike Pence's opinions the voice of America that historians will forever mark as America's true goals and motives?  Dan Quayle?  Algore, perhaps?  Grampa Badfinger?

Jefferson Davis' farewell address doesn't mention "a rise in abolitionist sentiment' in the slightest--which makes sense, since even in the North abolitionists were a tiny, despised minority.  He did complain about attempts to rile up bloody slave revolts (which, as he noted, was also in the US Declaration of Independence).  Jefferson Davis on other occasions spoke of the fact that slavery was doomed whether the Confederacy won the war or not, and stated during the war that we were not fighting for slavery but independence, but somehow the direct statements don't make it into any calculations.

It's amusing that the Daughters of the Confederacy have apparently become some diabolical Dixie Illuminati--a Dixienati?--that controls history, but they were basically a group of rape victims who sought to set the record straight.    Rather than knit blankets and talk about how nice slavery was, the UDC held burials and build memorials.  Amusingly, their commitment to immortalizing the heroism of Confederate women was more than any northerner was willing to credit the fairer sex with. 

It's also amusing that the 'Peaceful Protesters' have attacked the UDC headquarters...  but every office of the Sons of Confederate Veterans, an all-male organization, and the League of the South, a mostly-male organization, haven't seen any attacks.  Looks like some things never change.....

"Now you can tell me that's nonsense or call me a dumb yankee, which seems to be your MO, "
That really depends on your posts. You're wrong, but if you don't go around accusing me of supporting genocide, or consider "lying buffoon" to be an argument--not just worthy of using but defending as well--or toss around race-card bullshit, you're pretty safe.  (all those from this thread, btw.)

Whenever I referred to someone's argument as nonsense, I also took care to explain exactly why it was.  

So it's interesting that you've already decided you'll get such a response--the guilty flee when no man pursueth?--but the simple fact remains that states' rights, the proper role of the federal government, and the use of government to manage the economy had been big issues in American politics since long, long before the Southern states exercised our constitutional right to secede.  It had gone on...  well, really, with the colonists vs King George (the Dutch East India Company had been given an exclusive monopoly on tea in the colonies, which they knew would cost them a lot more than a measly 3% tax, which is exactly why the Boston Tea Party took place), but it continued with the Federalists vs the Antifederalists, with Clay vs Calhoun, and then Lincoln vs. Davis.  

Slavery was secure.  Not only did Lincoln and congress make clear they wouldn't do anything about it, but it was held as Constitutional (that's why we needed an amendment to change it, after all).  Abolitionists were a tiny, despised minority that politicians--including Lincoln himself--distanced himself from.  Slavery was more secure in the Union than it was out of it (a fact that Alexander Stephens acknowledged in a non-disputed quote, that somehow doesn't get so much notice).

On the other hand, the 1824 tariff caused an economic boom in the Northeast....  and in South Carolina, exports fell by 25%.  You tell me which one Southerners feared more.

replies.text:
Matthew Chenault A few things here:

1) Statues are easy to destroy, both physically (sledgehammers, ground tethers, and gravity) and chemically (dependant on the material used for creation of the statue). 

2) While books can be burned, the manuscripts and publishing of the books still exists. The statue exists as its own entity that isn't as recreatable as a book.

3)  The OP never said that quote was true. They merely attributed it and put it in the comments.

4) The weird living flesh and meat that generates an argument or quote doesn't automatically discredit the point being made. If it did, many reactionaries with easily debunked claims would never need more than 1 response video against them.

5) The destructibility of a medium does not change its message.

6) I genuinely don't know what you hope to accomplish after over a year of coming back to this comments section besides fishing for poorly worded responses among the well-reasoned ones you've received, or upping the overall comment count for this video, in which case you're helping the video in the YouTube algorithm.

replies.author: @Mark-the-Raider
replies.text:
Matthew Chenault  Do you not know of the Iliad? It's a story from Roman times that is essentially the Roman Odyssey. The Iliad was never a monument or construction. Aeneas's writings are still known, whereas many ruins are lost.

On your point of the Egyptians: the Rosetta Stone was extremely helpful in translating the language. Had we lacked any record of communication between Egyptians and Greeks, translating would have been harder. However, language analysis exists on languages we haven't fully translated or understood simply because of patterns common among languages that exist in writing. 

To claim I am "a truly evil person" is simply rude; you've not met me, nor do you understand my motivations. I don't seek to destroy things, as I agree with preserving historical structures and monuments. However, those monuments aren't always appropriate for a public space. 

Books are able to contextualize things, cites sources, and give a view on the events described, whether or not the depiction is accurate. Statues do not provide context. 

To make things abstract for a moment, imagine a person with a full understanding of the English language and no understanding of history. What do you think a statue of Jefferson Davis says to them? If it is publicly displayed, that implies they are worthy of some form of honor. The Constitution of the Confederacy grants much more context as to why the Confederate States came to be than the structures made decades after their time.

For the record, a mention of Hitler in an argument is not called reductum ad hitlerum, but Godwin's Law. You would also be using the wrong Latin gender suffix and case for Hitler.

author: @loonachan
text:
One Confederate general you rarely hear about from a lot of these people trying to glorify the confederacy is James Longstreet (you actually showed a picture of him, but that's really one of the only statues in existence, and it's on the battlefield in Gettysburg in Union territory, not in a southern town square). He was, in many war historian's opinion, one of if not the best military mind of the Civil War. He was at least a major reason why the rebellion lasted as long as it did, and played a key role in many battles. Yet, Longstreet is not talked about among neoconfederates, and it's easy to see why. After the war, he largely reversed his position that the Civil War was justified and accepted defeat, basically admitting the whole thing was a mistake. Many southern (hate) groups throughout history openly talked about how he should not be memorialized because he was inconvenient to their Lost Cause narrative. 

And to me that's all the proof you need that these statues are not memorializing history (whatever that means) or memorializing the great military minds and personalities in the war, because if that were the case, he would have just as many, if not more, statues and memorials than someone like Stonewall Jackson. It was all about racial and societal ideology at the time, trying to rewrite history.

replies.author: @loonachan
replies.text:
Stuart has a rather large statue in Richmond, and the only mar on his legacy is that he made a real mistake during Gettysburg (something Lee forced the Confederates into even though it was a stupid idea). Longstreet in reality made no big mistakes, and Confederate-friendly historians made up stuff about him to tar his legacy, and to this day there's almost no statues or commemorations of him outside his hometown. This is undoubtedly because he supported the Republican Party after the war and supported the freedom of blacks:

"Authors espousing the Lost Cause attacked Longstreet's war career for many years after his death. Modern authors trace that criticism to Longstreet's acceptance of the defeat and accommodations both with the Republican party and freed blacks. The attacks formally began on January 19, 1872, the anniversary of Lee's birth and less than two years after Lee died. Jubal Early, in a speech at Washington College, exonerated Lee for the defeat at Gettysburg and falsely accused Longstreet of having attacked late on the second day and of being responsible for the debacle on the third. The following year, William N. Pendleton, Lee's artillery chief, claimed in the same venue that Longstreet disobeyed an explicit order to attack at sunrise on July 2. Both allegations were fabrications; however, Longstreet failed to challenge them publicly until 1875. The delay damaged his reputation, as the Lost Cause mythology had now taken hold. Longstreet's former subordinate Col. John S. Mosby defended his commander, and other former Confederates who joined the Republican Party were subjected to similar criticism, including Gen. William Mahone and Robert W. Flournoy.

A "reconstructed rebel", Longstreet embraced equal rights for blacks, unification of the nation, and Reconstruction. After Longstreet died, his widow Helen Dortch Longstreet, privately published Lee and Longstreet at High Tide in his defense and stated that "the South was seditiously taught to believe that the Federal Victory was wholly the fortuitous outcome of the culpable disobedience of General Longstreet.""

I don't know why a "tragic" figure would be exempted from having statues made of him like all the rest. The fact is, when they were making many of these statues in the early 1900s, southerners hated Longstreet for being anti-Confederate after the war and told lies about how he disobeyed the Perfect God Lee's orders, even though Lee was the real reason they lost the war, if the war was ever winnable to begin with.

replies.text: Slightly related but I did a research project on Stand Watie, a Cherokee leader (not the chief if I remember correctly but had enough power to sign off on several controversial land treaties)  and the last Confederate general to surrender 1+ (again, fuzzy on the details) months after it officially ended. His legacy within the Cherokee community is still a topic of debate, but he was an incredibly accomplished general and is rarely mentioned. His brother (Watie helped) started the Cherokee Phoenix, the first indigenous nation wide newspaper that heavily swayed public opinion in some places on westward expansion and treaties. History is so fascinating but people defending these statues rarely stop to fully understand the context and range of it, or really engage with the actually important/interesting figures of the time

replies.author: @veloxian
replies.text:
Matthew Chenault Since you are boasting about taking macro economics theory I'd have to assume that you're purposefully misrepresenting the definition of trickle down economics to skew the argument in your favor. It was not "developed by Socialist advocates," and it does not refer to "downplaying the importance of deregulation and lowering taxes." It describes a policy of lowering taxes on the WEALTHY, which is the key bit you left out. More generally, it is the belief that if you lower taxes on the wealthy and increase incentives and subsidies for the wealthy, all classes of the nation will see benefit due to a "trickle down" effect. To make it even clearer, lowering taxes on the middle class and poor is NOT part of trickle down economics. Actual trickle down economics, which I just described, have been historically proven time and time again to not work. It leads to runaway income inequality and a massive deficit. Look no further than how the deficit exploded under Reagan. Actually...look a bit further, and you'll see Trump's tax cuts ballooning the deficit too.

You premise your argument on the government being too involved in the economy leading to monopolies. You then blame the existence of Google as a monopoly on the government being complicit and NOT being involved in the economy by not using anti-trust laws to stop them.....what?? I'm extremely confused. Was Reagan breaking up AT&T an example of the free market at work? Or overbearing government meddling?

replies.text: Matthew Chenault I have a degree in economics. What is referred to as trickle down economics is the laughable idea that cutting taxes will boost economic activity so much it will actually have a net effect of making the deficit smaller. That can certainly be the case in certain absurd tax scenarios. But all empirical evidence analyzed in economics journals shows we are not in that situation. Obviously tax cuts provide a stimulating effect on GDP. So do spending increases. And both increase in the deficit. A tax cut with a proportional cut in spending does not stimulate the economy. Maybe take more than an intro macro class before you pretend to understand economics. (Yes it’s still an intro class even with calculus, my college has no calc free macro classes, for instance)

replies.author: @adamestes5227
replies.text:
The Lenin statues in Seattle and NYC were imported from the former USSR by private citizens and erected on private property. 

Meanwhile, many of the Confederate statues are on public land (town squares, in front of courthouses, etc.) Public taxes are used to maintain these statues, which were erected largely after de jure segregation was instituted in the South, following the Supreme Court case Plessy V Ferguson in 1896 and cultural movements from the United Daughters of the Confederacy rewriting textbooks, raising money for monuments, and organizing public celebrations of all things CSA, and the premiere of The Birth Of A Nation in 1915, which was publicly endorsed by then President and historian, Woodrow Wilson, a firm advocate of the Lost Cause, who said of BOAN, “It is like writing history with lightning, and my only regret is that it is all so terribly true.”

I am for removing confederate statues, especially when they promote narratives that are not historically accurate. If you have a statue of a General on the site of a battlefield, I am ok with that. But imagine being a white southerner and being told, “You’re tax dollars will be partially spent to erect and maintain a statue of William Sherman on a horse, on a pedestal, in front of the courthouse of this town that was burned in his March to the Sea” Now imagine being black and realizing your taxes are being used to pay for a monument that seeks to justify the enslavement and discrimination of your ancestors, even if they were threatened with violence to comply with the society of the time.

replies.author: @Tenchigumi
replies.text:
​@bgh179 Rogan is the type who has a surface level understanding of a vast array of topics, but zero expertise on anything aside from maybe marijuana and certain aspects of MMA. Rogan is also very cognizant of that, so he's willing to listen to and learn from real experts (although he'll sometimes shut down shit that is blatantly false. Sometimes). That makes him a great bellweather for dudebros on current events, and can make him an excellent gateway for subjects that the average person wouldn't normally approach. The problem with Joe is that despite being left on most social issues, he's a sucker for "nice" people, and the alt-right FEEDS on that kind of gullible empathy, presenting themselves as these affable "normal but misunderstood" people, identifying the non-left issues Rogan leans towards (such as transgender discrimination), and then working him (and his fans) over from there. 


The worst part is that they've successfully convinced Joe that "SJWs" are this petty monolithic mob of outraged college kids with no real cause and a hatred for free speech, and guys like Rubin, Shapiro, Peterson and Harris will relentlessly feed into that notion, making him into a unwitting mouthpiece for a powerful tool in the fascist arsenal: the weaponized bastardization of "free speech." 

But seeing him shut down guys like Rubin and Crowder when they say dumb shit gives me hope.

replies.author: @davidmb1595
replies.text:
The marxism understander has logged on, it seems.
I know you'll never agree that you're wrong because your user name is Augusto Pinochet, but i'll try to reason with you even though I know I'll regret it later. 

You are the one who doesn't understand marxism (or methodologies in general, for that matter) Erasing history has been around since before Marx had even been born. The romans had this thing called Damnatio memoriae, where they literally erased someone from history, or tried to do it, we also have the example of people who deny the Armenian Genocide, people who claim that the USA won the Vietnam war, or the Holocaust deniers who do try to erase parts of their history, none of them are marxist in any sense, so even if erasing history were a marxist concepto (which is not) that wouldn't mean that every erasure of history ever would be marxist, because other do that too (even though marxist don't, in reality, but please bear with me). In order to demonstrate that erasing history is marxist, you'd have to either, explain how every instance of doing it is marxist or to point out any specific element in marxism that suggests doing it.
Now, according to marxism, there's a thing called superstructure, which is dependent on the structure. The structure is economical, so changing it would also change the superstructure, which is where our current narrative of history and tradition lie, so, that sentence you wrote "You have to deconstruct every aspect of the current capitalist system to replace it with true communism" is kinda true, but once you understand marxism (which you don't)  you realize that doing that doesn't require to erase history. 

Finally, let's talk about the Great Leap Forward. I'm going to be lenient with the fact that you're probably confused with the Cultural Revolution and you referred to the latter and tell you that it wasn't an attempt to to erase history, it was an attempt to get rid of bourgeoise elements present in the culture of China IN THE PRESENT and to also finish with some of the remaining elements of traditional Chinese culture that according to chairman Mao interfered with the revolution.  This has nothing to do with erasing history, since it isn't denying that certain events or things happened, but rather a prohibition against continuing doing such actions on the basis that they were harmful, wether you agree or disagree with Mao (I disagree, btw, since I do consider those would've naturally changed once capitalism had been overcome) you cannot compare his actions and goals with the erasure of history. Erasure of history is to pretend something didn't happen or to deliberately destroy it to make people forget about it and to prevent history from recording it. And well, even if the Cultural Revolution were an example of erasing history, it still wouldn't proof that erasure of history is a marxist concept, because China was the only example you can cherry pick of this being done, when there were lots of other marxist countries that didn't do it at all, that is a logical fallacy.  China's supposed erasure of history (that didn't happen, BTW) is so valid an example of erasure of history being marxist as Stalin's bringing up the images of the old tsars during World War 2 to inspire soviet soldiers is an example of it not being marxist at all. I hope you've understood you're wrong. I recommend further reading on marxism.

replies.author: @DG9-q6f
replies.text:
Matthew Chenault 
1. It still does not denigrate the right of this minority to think and say that the other position is morally wrong.

2. ThreeArrows was clear he was not speaking about cemetery monuments, and I do not think anyone in this tread suggested touching them. Yet, you are trying to connect these people (me included) to actions that none of them have condoned; as I said before, it's as productive as saying that you are connected to the crowd that likes shouting “Jews will not replace us” while marching with torches.

3. First, do I understand right that you no longer find it hypocritical to not attack Lincoln for racism but condemn confederate leaders for the constitution they were defending? Second, if Lincoln was really so bad (I don't have such an impression, but your word is heavier here), then I'd argue it's OK to attack his idolized position in US history: false heroes are dangerous for a nation's well-being (and they sometimes eclipse the true heroes that deserve more attention).

Yes, bones of the dead should not be dragged into politics; this is the reason I find the politically relevant timing of many confederate monuments built decades after the war quite repulsive.

replies.author: @DG9-q6f
replies.text:
I agree that it was stupid of me to mention that some of these monuments were made decades after the end of the war. However, I still feel convinced by the sources from both academia and relatives of the veterans that Three Arrows cites in the beginning of the video to show that some monuments were mainly set up for political reasons rather than to commemorate the dead (on top of Rogan's remark on how some of these monuments were set up with little regard for material quality just so that their timing was politically relevant).

Three Arrows clearly summarizes his vid in the end: he is for removing the statues from public non-educational spaces. Correct me if I am wrong, but a veteran's grave is not public, so the distinction is quite clear.

Also, it is excusable to own slaves when it is the norm, but I am afraid that forming your own government in order to include a slavery-protecting clause into your constitution goes beyond simple conformity right into active support of a sin. The latter is just much more grave an evil.

Lastly, I am not attacking Lincoln because to me he looks like a person who found himself in a situation he could not completely control and did the best he could; there are cases when “the ends justify the means” mentality renders your victory hollow, but I don't think it's one of them. However, as I said, I am much less aware of US history than of European history, so let's assume you are right and Lincoln was so bad he should not be celebrated at all, even despite all the things he did in the end. Will throwing him from spotlight be an attack on US history? I'd argue that the spotlight will be easily refilled with more deserving people from the era; there were plenty of statesmen and common abolitionists, both in the North and the South (the latter may be less numerous, but I'd say they had to have much bigger balls), that fought, and succeeded, in bringing slavery down.

I just don't see this process as an eternal road downhill: we are objectively in a better place than thousands of years ago, so on the whole our past is quite progressive and has a fair share of true heroes. However, accounting for the bad decisions and morally evaluating them is also extremely important: to learn from our mistakes and also to be sure that our own actions will be subject to such evaluations, where excuses such as “in the end I succeeded” or “I was just following orders/duty” will not fly with our descendants.

replies.author: @DG9-q6f
replies.text:
Thank you for taking the time to clarify this side of the story on why the monuments were built; it is hard for me to weight your arguments since I live in Europe, but I see that their history is more complicated than what I thought.

Perhaps I am interested in this debate because Russia, where I am from originally, people have similar problems with how to process both communist and imperial past, and whether valor can (or should) be considered separately from the cause a person was fighting for. Can valor and loyalty become so misplaced that a person can only be considered a hero if he has rejected them? In the end I think it can, and the world would be a better place if more people remembered that; of course it is unfair to many, but so is life in general. I want to underline though that such distinctions should be done on a strict case-to-case basis; I am just saying this so that you understood the reason for my perhaps excessive concern.

replies.author: @DG9-q6f
replies.text:
I get that things are emotionally charged around here, so it's OK to be rude sometimes.

While you are right about quite a bulk (perhaps majority, not sure) of the monuments in Soviet Russia serving propaganda purposes, one point where things become murkier is with monuments to Soviet soldiers of WW2 and whether they celebrate people who died for ridding Russia and a bulk of Europe from Nazis or an armed force that brought communism whenever it went. They are still supported by local Russian communities; most were set up by the state of course (with the rest set up only after USSR collapsed), but only because the "local level" option was not available due to time specifics.

I think in the end our main disagreement is whether it is possible to view an individual separately from the cause he was fighting for; I am closer to picking "no" as an answer, but this may be just due to cultural differences.

replies.author: @DG9-q6f
replies.text: On second thought, WW2 memorials may not be the best example, since most of the things that rub me the wrong way are caused by politicians of the "Make Russia USSR again" crowd and should be solved by kicking them as far away from said monuments as possible. The only situations relevant to your case are monuments to communist functionaries/Civil War veterans made in the cities where they come from, but it is still different due to lack of "for a small community" angle.

replies.author: @paulelkin3531
replies.text:
@franciemacleod The "1% opened slaves," figure is created by heavily cropping the data. 

First, this figure includes free states, where owning slaves was illegal. Looking only at slave states the figure jumps to 5%. And this still isn't entirely accurate, as some states where slavery was legal had very few slaves (Delaware is the best example). 

Including all the slave states, legally only the head of the family owned slaves, even though the whole family used them in the same manner: the percentage of families to own slaves was 20%. If you count by households (which is slightly broader), this jumps to 25%. 

Even the 25% figure isn't enterly accurate, because there was a lot of people who's job depended on slavery without them personally owning anyone. Most slave drivers managed slaves owned by someone else, and some people rented from richer families with larger numbers of slaves.

replies.author: @paulelkin3531
replies.text: Matthew Chenault Yes, three quarters is an overwhelming majority. Or did you get too triggered to notice you're repeating something I said?

replies.author: @DeadMarine1980
replies.text: Matthew Chenault because the majority of those poor soldiers (a lot of my great great grandfathers were those poor soldiers) who didn't own slaves fought for rich men to keep their slaves. That's why they keep “getting blamed".

replies.author: @paulelkin3531
replies.text:
Matthew Chenault Because the overwhelming majority of southerners were economically dependant on slavery and the overwhelming majority considered it right and proper, even at a time when most of the world had already repudiated slavery. 

And because I've seen this stupidity before, it is possible to be economically dependant on slavery without owning any slaves. Slave drivers often didn't own the slaves they worked, and a large number of people rented slaves. There's also the massive group of southerners who didn't directly work with slaves in any manner (although many of these worked with products produced by slaves) who supported slavery because it made them feel superior.

replies.author: @paulelkin3531
replies.text:
Matthew Chenault When the supporters of slavery realized the union was going to win, they made up a story to save face. The way to recognize a person who has "listened to or read anything from southerners concerning slavery," is to check whether they have noticed. Although I do enjoy that you assume people are physically capable of reading or listening to the words of slavers without agreeing with the slaver's claims.











Then we come to the people who did not own slaves, but were still economically dependent on slavery. For most slave drivers, their job was specifically to manage slaves owned by someone else. *Ignoring these people to defend slavery doesn't make them go away.* We also have all the people who shipped products produced by slaves up north and to Europe, as well as the people who sold to customers dependent of slavery to afford their goods. You have people who produced their own goods, owned their own land, and employed their own family in the family business who were dependent on buyers making their money through slavery. *Ignoring these people to defend slavery doesn't make them go away.* Even more glaringly obvious were the slave markets. If you're a laborer at a slave market you don't own any slaves, but are still dependent on slavery. If you're a salesman at a slave market, putting up other people's slaves for auction you are still dependent on slavery. If you get paid rent because salves are auctioned off on your property, that doesn't inherently mean you (or more accurately your family) own any slaves. *Ignoring these people to defend slavery doesn't make them go away.* 

Similarly, the way most plantation owners, factory owners, and yeoman farmers treated their slaves is not excused by the physical existence of a single individual who didn't treat their slaves as cruelly. If you're going to include Jackson, you might as well include Benjamin Franklin, who treated his slaves better. Specifically, Franklin freed them, took care of their families for the rest of his life, and became a staunch abolitionist after his trial run at owning other humans. There is a particular reason slaves fled the south at such a pace, and why, (as a completely hypothetical comparison, you understand) northern factory workers did not flood south. 

And of course, as I already mentioned in the comment that triggered you into responding, the 1% figure is created by counting the "big plantation owners," but not their families. Families that used (and I mean that in several senses) the slaves just as much as the person legally listen as the slave's owner on the paperwork. *Ignoring these people to defend slavery doesn't make them go away.*

replies.author: @paulelkin3531
replies.text:
Matthew Chenault Youtube is reaching new levels of stupidity it seems. The thrust of the erased portion, to the best of my ability to recall: 

Take John C. Calhoun, one of the major players in US politics you degenerates keep trying to erase. Unlike the soldier Jackson he was a politician, and in practice lead the south politically from the 1820's till he died. His specific position was to call slavery "a positive good," and insisted slavery benefited everyone involved. Note the principles under which the south seceded were specifically codified by Calhoun, as seen in the Nullification Crisis he created. This was the prevailing view of southerners, pretty much until they realized they were about to lose the civil war.

And as Virginia was left without any other southern states to supply it, southerners switched to claiming they had overwhelming considered slavery a "necessary evil." Or to dumb that down to a level you might be able to follow, they lied to sound less horrible when they realized the truth didn't support them. This becomes very obvious is you compare the writings of southern leaders before succession took place to their writing at the end of the civil war. 

Despite your feelings, those who were farmers weren't in the vast majority. The closest you get is Alabama, where they made up 68.3% of adult farmers over 15 in 1850 (this is cherry picked to be a state closer to your feelings). This figure *includes* the big plantation owners, the small plantation owners, the slave-owning yeomen (no matter much much their existence triggers you), and tenants and farm hands who didn't own any land. The figure would further drop if you include African Americans (who were mostly slaves) and women (of whom there were proportionally fewer farmhand laborers, thereby bringing down the percentage in agriculture). 

Also, the last sentence of the first paragraph should say "incapable."

replies.text:
Your first claim is ridiculous.  3-arrows consistently lashes out at Crowder--not "calmly explain[ing]" anything but spewing a consistent stream of slander.  In addition, Crowder wasn't wrong; Hitler was very much a socialist.

Amusingly, Fermin asks just how the US ever got a democratic country in the first place--the answer is by shooting people like 3 Arrows.

Second, since I pointed out what wasn't seen, it's fairly clear that I was referring to the OP's claim that he's seeing "Democracy=Communism."  Nobody is claiming that, and nobody is equating democracy to capitalism, and he has not seen it.  

The very idea that our country is lurching to the right is one of the dumbest I've ever seen--and seeing as this comment section is full of internet communists, that's saying something.  Imagine a Democrat Party 20 years ago, or 30, or 50, that's more than 50% socialist. @Kingoftherednex Communism (even though all the stuff people have written and said about it, positive and negative) is still pretty unclear. Like all human constructs, it is really hard to define clearly. Socialism is when you allow everyone to be more equal by, as you state, taking resources from those who have more than plenty and giving it to those who have few.  Many ideologies try to do this, although all of them only give the wealth to a single group, for example Hitler wanted all of the recourses to go to the "superior race". Actual Socialism is [meant] to be for everybody.

Communism is another step up where everybody is forced into being completely equal in status and wealth. Some people say this is anarchic, and I agree, since this will never work at all, and almost all of its policies are less about the people being equal and more about them being suppressed.

You can certainly place ideologies on a range of good and bad, but there will always be the ones in the middle. It isnt as clean as half good half bad. Also, that comment on socialism can be applied to essentially any ideology (capitalism being one, with CEO's stealing the wealth of the company etc. ect.).

That all being said, things like a 40 hour work week, a two day weekend, universal suffrage, and the civil rights movement are all examples of socialist (or at least labor union) policies implemented well. None of them lead to America turning into a dystopian nightmare, so why would things like universal healthcare? If its bad and works out horribly (which it totally might), we as Americans can simply decide to vote out the leaders that implemented them and reverse everything. Trump has taken steps to take down Obamacare and made the US leave the Paris Agreement after all. If someone somehow take power with force and takes away democracy to attempt to restart the Soviet Union, I advocate universal gun rights for a reason.

author: @dogeyes7261
text:
White Southerner here*. I’m also a dreaded marxist-leninist, one who’s even read the dastardly writings of the white-hating Black Panthers! At least, that’s what I was raised to believe. 

There’s a lot of complicated history here that is simply ignored. 14% of my state voted for Eugene V Debs, the self proclaimed American Bolshevik, who spent time in prison for his vocal opposition to World War 1 and for agitating for revolution.

However, you wouldn’t know that reading current Louisiana History textbooks. You also won’t learn that the anarchist Industrial Workers of the World organized one of the first interracial unions here, that the Knights of Labor organized an interracial union in my hometown with a 10,000 strong strike that was put down by white militia killing anywhere from dozens to hundreds of people in the Thibodaux Massacre. You probably won’t hear about the utopian socialist colony of New Llano, although the town with that name is still there. You won’t hear about the 1930s strike of fishermen, utilizing armed resistance over low prices for catches, although a documentary was produced in the 1970s entitled “Huit Pieces et Demi!” which was the strikers’ slogan. 

You will maybe hear about slave rebellions, like the 1811 German Coast Uprising. 

But where are the statues and plaques to commemorate this history? 

The bus boycott tactic made famous by Rosa Parks originated in Baton Rouge. The New Orleans Black Panthers were ambushed and shot up by a police raid. Three Panthers spent 30 years in solitary confinement after this raid, first arrested for defending themselves from the police, and then framed for the murder of a guard, really they were punished for daring to organize an end to prison violence and racial gangs to unite the prisoners. 

None of this history is commemorated and it’s hardly ever discussed. Any resistance to exploitation or racism is hidden, for obvious reasons, especially if the resistance broke down racial walls.

This is the real revisionism. And it damages the psyche of poor and working people of all races and nations. It makes racism seem universal, hegemonic, and inevitable. It makes exploitation seem natural, inescapable, even if you hate it. 

*I’m actually a Cajun-Creole, a group of people that hardly enlisted to fight in the Civil War, and had an extremely high desertion rate. We saw the war as “an American problem.” We didn’t really think of ourselves as American until sometime after World War 2, with forced Americanization and proletarianization. This doesn’t mean we didn’t and don’t have problems with racism and white supremacy. It does mean that for us to stop being “white n****ers,” as Anglos called us, French and Spanish had to be beaten out of us. The US oil companies feared violent resistance to the necessary despoliation of the land in service of the oil industry, and finally sought to proletarianize and Americanize us to avoid this after neglecting us for almost 100 years.

Matthew Chenault, absolutely. That's what makes Lincoln the first great, moral US president. The slave states were a cesspool of moral depravity. And most people there never changed.

There was one great man in the slave south. General William Mahone, who was also the greatest military leader of the Confederacy. Lee was an average leader, but unlike Mahone, he wasn't a "race traitor."

Senator William Mahone was one of the most maligned political leaders in post-Civil War America. He was also one of the most capable. Compared to the Roman traitor Cataline (by Virginia Democrats), to Moses (by African American congressman John Mercer Langston), and to Napoleon (by himself), Mahone organized and led the most successful interracial political alliance in the post-emancipation South. Mahone’s Readjuster Party, an independent coalition of black and white Republicans and white Democrats that was named for its policy of downwardly “readjusting” Virginia’s state debt, governed the state from 1879 to 1883.

During this period, a Readjuster governor occupied the statehouse, two Readjusters represented Virginia in the United States Senate, and Readjusters represented six of Virginia’s ten congressional districts. Under Mahone’s leadership, his coalition controlled the state legislature and the courts, and held and distributed the state’s many coveted federal offices. A black-majority party, the Readjusters legitimated and promoted African American citizenship and political power by supporting black suffrage, office-holding, and jury service.  To a degree previously unseen in Virginia, and unmatched anywhere else in the nineteenth-century South, the Readjusters became an institutional force for the protection and advancement of black rights and interests.

At the state level, the Readjusters separated payment of the school tax from the suffrage, thereby enfranchising thousands of Virginia’s poorest voters.  They restored and reinvigorated public education in the state, and they lowered real estate and personal property taxes.  They banned the chain gang and the whipping post.  At the municipal level, Readjuster governments paved streets, added sidewalks, and modernized water systems.

The Readjusters lost power in 1883 through a Democratic campaign of violence, electoral fraud, and appeals to white solidarity. While Democrats suppressed progressive politics in the state, other groups of elite white Virginians worked fast to eradicate the memory of Virginia’s experiment in interracial democracy. These were mutually reinforcing projects. Convinced that black enfranchisement was “the greatest curse that ever befell this country,” members of the Association for the Preservation of Virginia Antiquities (APVA), founded in 1889, equated the Readjuster’ rule with “mobocracy” and called for radical pruning of the electorate. After 1900, William Mahone was characterized by whites in Virginia as a demagogic race traitor with autocratic tendencies. This representation was so powerful that as late as the 1940s the worst charge that could be brought against an anti-Democratic opposition candidate was that he had been associated with Mahone and the Readjusters.

By March 13, 1865, the Confederacy had its back against the wall, and by the less than overwhelming margin of 40 to 37 in the House, and nine to eight in the Senate, the Confederate congress approved a bill to allow Jefferson Davis to require a quota of black soldiers from each state. Presumably (although the bill did not say so) slaves who fought would, if they survived the war, be freed. Southerners who opposed using blacks in the army noted that this idea had its problems: First, it was obvious that the Yankee armies would soon free them anyway; and second, if slavery was so wonderful and happy for black people, why would one be willing to risk death to win his freedom?

The very accurate point made then by opponents of this legislation was, as one Georgia leader stated, "If slaves will make good soldiers our whole theory of slavery is wrong." Southern newspaper editors blasted the idea as "the very doctrine which the war was commenced to put down," a "surrender of the essential and distinctive principle of Southern civilization."

The war was virtually over by then, and when black Union soldiers rode into Richmond on April 3, they found two companies of black men beginning to train as potential soldiers. When those black men had marched down the street in Confederate uniforms, local whites had pelted them with mud. None got into the war, and Lee surrendered on April 9.

Some guy wrote the other day, YOU Millennials don't know history, like when Abe Lincoln attacked Fort Sumter.
The First Battle of Fort Sumter began on April 12, 1861, when *Confederate artillery fired on the Union garrison* . These were the *first shots of the war and continued all day* , watched by many civilians in a celebratory spirit. The fort had been cut off from its supply line and surrendered the next day. The Second Battle of Fort Sumter (September 8, 1863) was a failed attempt by the Union to retake the fort, dogged by a rivalry between army and navy commanders. Although the fort was reduced to rubble, it remained in Confederate hands until it was evacuated as General Sherman marched through South Carolina in February 1865.

Third, I never said the Aztecs or Incas were saints, though they were FAR from the only victims of the conquistadors. Just because some of the victims were also assholes doesn't absolve the Conquistadors of their crimes. The Aztecs and Inca had never harmed the Spanish, there were not threats to them, they were simply rich targets. And then other groups like the Arawak of the Antilles were still enslaved despite welcoming the Spanish peacefully and not maintaining cruel empires. This argument is vacuous.

The conquistadors were evil, by the standards of their own time, by the standards of our time, by the standards of the people they conquered and even the people who paid for their voyages. It's acknolwedging historical reality with no implications that any currently living person is guilty of any of these crimes. Conquistadores did commit many crimes, but it was not approved by the crown, so many of them were punished. But here you were saying that they were "evil" even when compared with the morality of their times. Some of them were evil, some were not. And on average, Spanish colonization was less brutal than any other European power (as you can see with the examples I gave). 

Seriously, if Spanish conquest was soooooo evil, why did they obtain help from local natives in the process? Mexico, a region of +1M people was conquered by less than 1.400 soldiers, thanks to significant local support. The conquest was maintaned by continuous collaboration. 

If you were a galo, and you were conquered by the Romans, it was a very traumatic and cruel process. No conquest was "ethical". But if I was a pre-columbine native, it was much better to be conquered by the Spaniards, than by the Dutch, the English or the French... or even the Aztecs....

First of all, 80-90% of all native population in America died because of diseases brought from the Old World, and those deaths were inevitable. 
Second, Pizarro, the conquistador of the Inca Empire, was much worse than Pizarro (Mexico), so he caused much more suffering, actually the Potosi mines were the most important mines, and were probably they abused more of native local force to extract the silver. 
Third, if Spanish local Government was so much worse than the Inca, the logical step was a rebellion, especially when Spaniards were hugely outnumbered by local forces (and the use of gunpowder was very limited at that time), so it looks exaggerated. 
Forth, I'm not denying that many Conquistadores were cruel bastards (Pizarro was one of the worst), but I deny that the average Spanish govern system was so evil, especially when compared to other historical alternatives (French, English, Dutch, Aztecs...).

Alright but credit should be given where credit is due. The colonial Peru was one of the times when it was most united and well internally connected. 
It should be clear by now that I can only speak about the case of Peru, and am not confident enough to make a case for other ex-Spain colonies. Spain gets blamed a lot for the current inequalities, and it might have started with them, but it’s the fuckers that took control after the independence who have more of the blame, who instead of correcting the problems worsened the inequality and the racism.

replies.author: @KingBobXVI
replies.text:
@garyjustice6888 - "The top ten things that caused the war, slavery was in the bottom 5"

That's a flat lie, and you know it.
Slavery _was_ a dying institution years before, but with the invention of the cotton gin, cotton became a viable crop that subsisted on... wait for it... slavery. At the time of the war, slavery was alive and well. If it wasn't the main priority, the confederate states wouldn't have kept talking about it in most of their articles of secession, especially not as, you know, the primary reason for leaving. "It was economics" is a dumb point, because their economic system was based on slavery. "States rights" is also in that category, since the only "states right" they cared about was "right to own slaves" - they were actively _against_ state rights when it came to northern states refusing to return escaped slaves. Ever hear of the Fugitive Slave Acts? The south then - and still now - have only ever been "states rights for me, not for thee". The articles of confederation even expressly forbid member states from banning slavery - so much for "states rights".

"Lincoln wasn't a literal angel" - nobody cares nor claimed it (except republicans when they want to fallate themselves as "the party of Lincoln", then they forget the civil war somehow). To the north, the war was about keeping the union together. To the south, it was entirely about slavery.

The north _was_ however pushing for a slow end to slavery, since all the anti-slave representatives were in the north, and the government had determined that new states in the west north of a certain line would be free states, and south would be slave states. Eventually though, more states would have been free than slave, and the practice would lose support, which is where they saw the writing on the wall and decided secession was the only option left.

"How can you be so left or right on this."

I don't know, maybe ask yourself? Why do you choose to take a hard right-wing approach to revisionist history? And the ridiculous 'TaXaTiOn AnD rEgUlAtIoN iS sLaVeRy" bullshit - aren't you quite the tool.

replies.text: Look it up, bud. Lincoln wanted a wage-based economy. And to be honest, Lincoln did overstep his executive bounds. But he I'm glad he did because he and his cabinet knew what was best for the country, which was to get away from slave based economy and create a strong central government.

replies.author: @dudders91
replies.text:
Nah, strong central government is what makes America powerful and structured. It gives the common man: wage based economy, end to slavery, strong centralized military for defense, law and order, highways-railroads-basically all transportation, unified currency that isn't restricted by the gold standard, civil rights, economic protections, etc. 

It's also important for States to ensure checks and balances and remain powerful themselves, but the United States without a strong central government in the modern era would be a complete and utter catastrophe for the working class and the lower class. Like it or not, the U.S. government provides a number of services for you on a daily basis.

replies.author: @dudders91
replies.text: Well, define basic rights and how they eroded, because that's pretty broad. Are you talking about Citizens United? Because I'm staunchly for overturning that. Do you mean voting rights? Because those have been INFINITELY improved since having a centralized government. Some counties would have tests that consisted of guessing how many marbles in a jar before you could vote- that was under local rule. Government in the United States has given us many rights and equalities, so what exactly are you referring to?

replies.author: @dudders91
replies.text: Anyway we've come away from the initial talking point here. I think there's a debate to be had about small vs. big government but we were talking about the point you made about Lincoln overstepping his bounds as president. What exactly do you see as so sinister about that? The draft? The establishment of a standing federal army? A law which declared that all men should be declared as equal?

replies.author: @dudders91
replies.text:
It's a nice idea, but those rights don't always exist without the government. Just look at all of the people who were lynched after the Civil War. The states that allowed this should have met the federal standard of justice but chose not to and as a result many, many people were wrongfully murdered. I'll meet you halfway however. Maybe government doesn't "give" us our rights, but I will argue that it "defines" what our rights as citizens are. And just to be clear- I am very much for something of a middle ground. I think that freedom and local community/government is very important. I'm just arguing for central government and that you need to have both for equilibrium (checks and balances and all that). 


The essence of what I'm saying in response to your comments is that, yes, Lincoln certainly overstepped his executive bounds, but at the time that is what the situation called for and I think he handled it expertly. At other times it is important for local governments to call in question the actions of the federal branch. It's all part of the ebb and flow. Different times call for different strategies. 


And listen, I'm not super educated on the pronoun issue you brought up- if it is true you can spend time in jail for not using someone's correct pronoun, then I definitely have issue with that. But as you said this is a thing being decided on a local level at the moment so it's not the federal government. Therefore I would argue bringing that up goes against your whole point.

replies.author: @dudders91
replies.text:
I see a lot of your points and concede in agreeing that Lincoln and his admin were clearly creating a new definition of executive power. That being said, we are disagreeing on one fundamental point here: the South did not act in a response to Lincoln. Lincoln acted in response to the South. The Civil War had been brewing long before Lincoln came into office. The South wanted to secede before Lincoln. Lincoln, in fact, had a rather moderate view on slavery when first elected and was going to allow the South continue the practice. He was against expansion but would not meddle where it was already a thing. We did not see a radicalized Lincoln until his second term, in which he then decided to end slavery completely. But since you raise some valid disputes I'll try and give some links with more perspective. 

Lincoln suspends habeus corpus: Well the confederates were the enemy and the president didn't want them organizing in Maryland where the government was centered. I'm not saying it's completely justified but it's easy to see how this was a strategic advantage. https://www.reference.com/history/did-lincoln-suspend-writ-habeas-corpus-95b63b23300c340d

The draft: Unfortunate to say the least. I can't attest to the necessity of it during the Civil War but I can understand it if it was an absolute necessity to defeat the South. Interesting you would bring up the riots though because the amount of violence would be completely unjustifiable by today's standards of Baltimore and Ferguson. In fact. many blacks were slain unjustly during this riot. https://www.history.com/topics/american-civil-war/draft-riots


Your view similar to how my friends from South Carolina were taught the Civil War. Fortunately this was a fairly well-documented event in our history and much of the "Lost Cause" has been debunked for some time. In the "War of Aggression" the aggressors were the South, who wanted to expand into Central America and feared that the federal government would abolish their slave trade. They attacked Fort Sumter of their own volition. And I would argue that Lincoln did an exceptional job taking control of what could have been the complete annihilation of the "United" States. 


http://www.historynet.com/causes-of-the-civil-war

author: @Houseofweird
text:
In my home city of Bristol in the UK, the statue of slaver Edward Colston was finally pulled down in 2020 after various parties had tried for decades to have his statue removed, finding the idea of celebrating a man responsible for the transport of 84000 captured human beings to the Americas (of which up to 19000 died on the Middle Passage) offensive. The Merchant Venturers (the society who'd originally put it up) resisted and argued that while slavery was regrettable, for Colston and his peers it was just business and he had been a huge benefactor to the city (for the record, his statue went up in 1895,  over 170 years after he'd died as a reminder of his philanthropic contributions to Bristol).

Since the statue was pulled down and covered so widely in the news, more people than ever know about Colston, including outside the UK. History didn't die with the removal of his statue, it was given a new lease of life.

author: @draochvar9646
text:
I'd personally say there is three ways to deal with these statues: 
1. If they are of little material and artistic value and hold little to no historic value beyond being lost cause tripe, scrap them.
2. If they are well made, have a history that justifies the effort and can be removed, give them over to a museum that is up to the task of adequately presenting them, where they can be displayed and the full context of their purpose and meaning can be explained.
3. If it isn't possible to move them or if there's no museum that will take them, turn their meaning into something positive by building educational sites around them. Install informational plaques (not little ones, big ones, all around them) and big info-tables, that tell a passerby who built them and what the malicious intent behind that was.
 This has been done to great effect here in Germany and Austria with certain pieces of Nazi art and architecture. In essence: turn them from artifacts of the Lost Causers into sites that educate people on the evils of historic revisionism.

Because - for those who do not know - the first thing to lead them to know of that history is seeing a monument and asking yourself _who_ is this and _why_ they are there. 

It’s no different to a headstone. The headstone - itself - is a gateway into the past; it reaches from within the grave and - but for a moment - reveals the life of a man who’d been dead for countless years. Without it, you would not think once of it. 

Without a headstone, a grave is merely a depression in the ground; something you could easily miss. 

Without a monument upon a battlefield, a trench is merely an embankment of dirt. A hill is just a hill. It is merely what it appears to be and nothing more. You _need_ monuments to _convey_ something to the posterity of the generations. Otherwise, it will be lost.

Monuments - whether one wishes to admit it or not - are critical in telling the history of the events that happened. Without them, there is no drive to learn these things and - in turn - that history will be forgotten; locked away behind a barrier designed by those who seek to control that history for themselves.

replies.author: @MatthewChenault
replies.text:
In fact, I can point to several instances where a monument led to me learning about a historical figure. 

In Monroe Park in Richmond, Virginia, I saw the statue of Williams Carter Wickham. Out of curiosity, I decided to stop and read about the man’s history. From it, I came to _admire_ the man and understood _why_ he had a monument. 

The position of monuments not carrying historical value is ignorant. It is based off of a presumption of everyone having absolute historical knowledge and a lack of personal experience to understand _why_ those things exist.

author: @Maxim89Il
text:
I was long undecided whether Confederate monuments in the South should be preserved or not. I mean, any decent person would agree that the Confederates were scum... but still, monuments are history, and I don't support the destruction of art or statues no matter how much of a scumbag the subject of the piece was.

We know Nero was a tyrant, we known Henry VIII was voted as the worst monarch in British history for a good reason, we know Genghis Khan was infamous for a reign of terror... but despite all of those personas being absolute degenerates, I doubt anyone would suggest demolishing their monuments, right? I mean, the presence of their monuments does not in any way represent that anyone would like to resurrect them into power today.

However, here is why I've come to the conclusion that Confederate monuments should be demolished. Not only that, but I think the Confederate flag (or flags) should be banned from official use... just like the Nazi flag is not waved around Germany.

See, while the historical figures I've mentioned are well in the past and have no modern ideological claim... the Confederate ideology is still out there. I mean, it started not long after the end of the Civil War, and lasts to this day, the neo-Confederate ideology and the "Lost Cause" nonsense.

I've done my research in various political Facebook groups, and I was horrified to see how much there is an attempt to justify what the Confederacy did. Neo-Confederates attempt to push the "Lost Cause" narrative, claiming the Civil War was not about slavery but about "state rights"... they just omit the part how the "right" they were talking about was mainly the "right" to hold other beings as slaves.

All of the slave women raped, all of the men whipped, all of the abuse, the chains, the humiliation... nope, neo-Confederates conveniently cut it out.

And that ideology never stopped! The lynching continued well into the 20th century. In the 1920, the KKK peaked 6,000,000 members, that was Confederate ideology right there. The horrific segregation laws continued into the 1960s, and same was with the anti-miscegenation laws that literally had humans sent to prison for having interracial relationships.

But that didn't stop in the 1960s! In 2017, a violent rally took part in Charlottsville, Virginia, called "United the Right Rally" against the removal of Confederate monument. In the rally, Confederate and Nazi flags were waved.

The reason I support the removal of Confederate monuments is because that ideology, the horrific and vile ideology of slavery and the subjugating of other human beings, is still there! The dehumanisation of black people is still there. Those monuments are part of that ideology and are used to preserve it.

And you know what? I honestly understand where neo-Confederates are coming from... it's not easy to admit your ancestors were lowlife scum who fought to preserve slavery, so you create a new narrative. Will the descendants of  Nazi soldiers try the same in the future? Who knows.

And yes, I know not all Confederate soldiers were for slavery, some were drafted against their will... and? So were many soldiers serving in the German Army in WWII. Your point is...? The ones with a moral compass deserted, and the ones with a moral compass and courage did what the great Newton Knight and the Free State of Jones did, and resisted the Confederate regime.

Those monuments need to be demolished, pretty much as we don't have Nazi monuments around today. 

No black child should have to walk past a monument which was the gathering point of those who violently lynched his great uncle, and which still serves as a gathering point for those who lament the loss of the Confederacy and lament the abolition of slavery.

author: @EliseLogan
text:
As a direct descendant - from multiple lines - of at least 3 of the people to whom these monuments are commonly erected - yes. They should all come down. Every one of them should be removed. Teaching the history of racism in the United States does not require statues glorifying slavery, racism, and hatred. All the things named after them - all the roads, schools, public buildings - should be renamed. None of that will affect what is included in history books. Maintaining things like battlefields (Manassas or Gettysburg or Vicksburg, for example) or war hospitals or other similar actually historically relevant locations is sufficient - and can present the information in the light of historical scholarship rather than racist screed.
I live in VA - and in this state there are currently multiple armed forces installations named for confederate leaders, multiple roads named for them, many statues erected to them. But there is also the Manassas battlefield - and that does more to actually illuminate the history of the conflict than any of the other things mentioned. Keep that one.

Oh, and in re: slippery slope - okay. So what? Even if the slippery slope happens and ALL statues of individual leaders are removed - inclusive of Mt. Rushmore (Which is, absolutely, a monument of white supremacy, taking a sacred Native location and defacing it with images of the culture which killed and dislocated an enormous percentage of Natives. And it was done by a man with specific and clear ties to white supremacist groups, so this was no accident.), so what? No history is lost. The books and documents still tell the history. The battlefields still exist. If we took every single statue to any individual down, possibly replacing some with historical markers or ... I don't know, models of the water molecule... it would make no actual difference to historical knowledge.

author: @TheSovietSuperpower
text:
Ok, minor nitpick, but at 24:09, the picture of the monument you used is dedicated to Andrew Jackson, a US President with the inscription "The Union Must and Shall be Preserved" actually in the frame, which was added to the monument after the Union recaptured New Orleans from the Confederacy in 1862. Now I'm of the opinion that statues of Jackson (along with other US Presidents like Washington for example) should he taken down due to their racist past. However, I am nothing if not a Klugscheißer, and to use a picture of a US President with an inscription added after the Union recaptured the largest city in the Confederacy with the added inscription Glorifying the Union cause in the picture and insinuating that it is an example of a Confederate monument is simply wrong, and while I'm of the opinion that it should be taken down anyways, I point this out to give you a heads up before some opportunistic fascist comes trolling on your video and points out this mistake and "puts their finger in the bullet hole" so to speak.

All that being said, I did enjoy the video. Keep up the good work!
